docs.title: Welcome to MkDocs Tutorial
docs.text: This is a comprehensive tutorial and example site for MkDocs with the Material theme. Here you'll find examples of various features and capabilities that MkDocs offers.

docs.title: Features Demonstrated
docs.text:
• Complete Documentation Structure - See how to organize your documentation effectively
  • Material Theme Customization - Examples of theme customization and features
  • Markdown Extensions - Various markdown extensions and their usage
  • Search Functionality - Built-in search feature
  • Responsive Design - Works great on all devices

docs.title: Quick Links
docs.text:
• Getting Started - Learn how to set up MkDocs
  • Markdown Examples - See markdown formatting examples
  • Admonitions - Learn about admonitions and callouts

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you need help with MkDocs, you can:

  • Read the official MkDocs documentation
  • Visit the Material for MkDocs website
  • Check the PyMdown Extensions documentation

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
• mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project.
  • mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server.
  • mkdocs build - Build the documentation site.
  • mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit.

docs.title: Project layout
docs.text:
mkdocs.yml    # The configuration file.
docs/
    index.md  # The documentation homepage.
    ...       # Other markdown pages, images and other files.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: This documentation serves as a comprehensive guide and example for MkDocs with the Material theme. It demonstrates various features and capabilities that you can use in your own documentation.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Material Design theme
  • Responsive layout
  • Dark mode support
  • Search functionality
  • PDF export capability
  • Various Markdown extensions

docs.title: Contact
docs.text: If you have any questions or suggestions about this documentation, please feel free to reach out.

docs.title: Version Information
docs.text:
• MkDocs version: 1.5+
  • Material theme version: 9.0+
  • Python version: 3.8+

docs.title: License
docs.text: This documentation is licensed under the MIT License.

docs.title: Acknowledgments
docs.text: Special thanks to: - The MkDocs team - Material for MkDocs creators - All contributors

docs.title: Admonitions
docs.text: Admonitions, also known as call-outs, are an excellent way to highlight important information.

docs.title: Basic Admonitions
docs.text:
Note

This is a note admonition. Use it for general information.

Tip

This is a tip admonition. Use it for helpful tips and tricks.

Warning

This is a warning admonition. Use it to warn users about potential issues.

Danger

This is a danger admonition. Use it for critical information that needs attention.

Success

This is a success admonition. Use it to indicate successful operations.

docs.title: Collapsible Admonitions
docs.text:
Click me to expand

This is a collapsible admonition. It starts collapsed.

Expanded by default

This is a collapsible admonition that starts expanded.

docs.title: Custom Titles
docs.text:
Custom Title

You can customize the title of any admonition.

docs.title: Nested Admonitions
docs.text:
Outer note

This is an outer note.

Inner warning

This is a nested warning inside a note.

docs.title: Supported Types
docs.text:
• note
  • abstract
  • info
  • tip
  • success
  • question
  • warning
  • failure
  • danger
  • bug
  • example
  • quote

docs.title: Basic Code Block
docs.text:
def greet(name):
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

print(greet("World"))

docs.title: Code with Line Numbers
docs.text:
class Calculator:
    def add(self, a, b):
        return a + b

    def subtract(self, a, b):
        return a - b

    def multiply(self, a, b):
        return a * b

    def divide(self, a, b):
        if b == 0:
            raise ValueError("Cannot divide by zero")
        return a / b

docs.title: Code with Highlighting
docs.text:
def process_data(data):
    # This line is highlighted
    result = data.process()
    return result

docs.title: JavaScript
docs.text:
function fetchData() {
    return fetch('https://api.example.com/data')
        .then(response => response.json())
        .then(data => console.log(data));
}

docs.title: HTML
docs.text:
<div class="container">
    <h1>Hello World</h1>
    <p>This is a paragraph.</p>
</div>

docs.title: CSS
docs.text:
.container {
    max-width: 1200px;
    margin: 0 auto;
    padding: 20px;
}

docs.title: Inline Code
docs.text: You can use inline code within paragraphs.

docs.title: Code with Title
docs.text:
example.py
def main():
    print("This is a code block with a title")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

docs.title: Markdown Examples
docs.text: This page demonstrates various Markdown features supported by MkDocs.

docs.title: Basic Formatting
docs.text:
Bold text and italic text

Bold and italic text

~~Strikethrough text~~

docs.title: Lists
docs.text:
Unordered list:

  • Item 1
  • Item 2
    • Subitem 2.1
    • Subitem 2.2
  • Item 3

Ordered list:

  1. First item
  2. Second item
  3. Third item

Task list:

  • [x] Completed task
  • [ ] Incomplete task
  • [ ] Another task

docs.title: Tables
docs.text: Header 1 Header 2 Header 3 Cell 1 Cell 2 Cell 3 Cell 4 Cell 5 Cell 6

docs.title: Blockquotes
docs.text:
This is a blockquote

It can span multiple lines

And can be nested

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
Inline code: print("Hello, World!")

Code block with syntax highlighting:

def hello_world():
    print("Hello, World!")
    return True

# Function call
hello_world()

docs.title: Links and Images
docs.text: Link to Google

docs.title: Footnotes
docs.text: Here's a sentence with a footnote1.

docs.title: Definition Lists
docs.text:
Term 1 Definition 1 Term 2 Definition 2 Definition 2.1

  1. This is the footnote content. ↩

docs.title: Colors and Fonts
docs.text:
You can customize the Material theme by modifying the mkdocs.yml file:

theme:
  name: material
  palette:
    primary: indigo
    accent: indigo
  font:
    text: Roboto
    code: Roboto Mono

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Configure the navigation structure:

nav:
  - Home: index.md
  - User Guide:
    - Getting Started: guide/getting-started.md
    - Customization: guide/customization.md

docs.title: Adding Extensions
docs.text:
Enable Markdown extensions in mkdocs.yml:

markdown_extensions:
  - admonition
  - codehilite
  - toc:
      permalink: true

docs.title: Custom CSS
docs.text:
Create a docs/stylesheets/extra.css file:

:root {
  --md-primary-fg-color: #007bff;
}

Then add it to mkdocs.yml:

extra_css:
  - stylesheets/extra.css

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
To get started with MkDocs, you'll need Python installed on your system. Then you can install MkDocs using pip:

pip install mkdocs
pip install mkdocs-material

docs.title: Creating a New Project
docs.text:
1. Create a new project: 

    mkdocs new my-project
cd my-project

  2. Start the development server: 

    mkdocs serve

  3. Open your browser and visit http://127.0.0.1:8000

docs.title: Project Layout
docs.text:
mkdocs.yml    # The configuration file
docs/
    index.md  # The documentation homepage
    ...       # Other markdown pages, images and other files

docs.title: Basic Commands
docs.text:
• mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server
  • mkdocs build - Build the documentation site
  • mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit

Pro Tip

Use mkdocs serve during development to preview your changes in real-time!

docs.title: Basic Markdown
docs.text: MkDocs uses Markdown for content creation. Here are some basic examples:

docs.title: Headers
docs.text:
# H1 Header
## H2 Header
### H3 Header

docs.title: Text Formatting
docs.text:
**Bold text**
*Italic text*
`Code text`

docs.title: Adding Images
docs.text:
When adding images, use the following format to ensure proper PDF rendering:

![Alt text](image.jpg){ width="300" }

docs.title: Tables
docs.text:
Create tables using the following syntax:

| Header 1 | Header 2 |
|----------|----------|
| Cell 1   | Cell 2   |

docs.title: Code Blocks
docs.text:
Use triple backticks with language specification:

def hello_world():
    print("Hello, World!")

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use relative links for internal navigation
  2. Keep image sizes consistent
  3. Use proper heading hierarchy
  4. Include alt text for images
  5. Maintain consistent formatting
